Hopkins, Institute Start
'No Credit'Exchange
By,ANDREW GREEN
Hopkins students can now take courses at
the Maryland Institute of Art, and vice
versa, under a newly negotiated but not yet
finalized agreement between the two
schools._
The question of academic credit remains
unresolved.
The arrangement, similar to the existing
one between Hopkins and Goucher College,
will not cost students at either institution
any extra tuition. Dean Strider is expected
to pass final judgement on the agreement
soon.
But the experience of the lone student
currently taking part in the program
indicates that the kinks have not yet been
worked out. Dennis Krohn, a Hopkins
senior, signed up at the Institute for a Basic
Drawing course. He then had to arrange for
his tuition to be paid by Hopkins to the
Institute.
"Apparently," stated Krohn, "no
administrative mechanism for arranging
the tuition exchange exists yet at Hopkins.
The matter is still unresolved," said Krohn,
"but he is taking the course anyway."
"I haven't even tried to hassle the matter
of credit. I don't think Hopkins will be
accepting credit for Institute courses,"he
remarked.
Phil Payne, a Hopkins sophomore, said
he was going to take a photography course
at the Institute, but was told by

administrators here that Hopkins did not
grant credit for studio courses. Payne
noted, however, that the school's policy is
inconsistent.
"I took a photography course at Loyola
over the minimester that was purely a
studio course. Yet I did get credit for it. "
Dean Benton stated it was an Academic
Council policy not to give credit for studio
courses. "A studio course might be
acceptable for credit," he indicated, "if it
contained a significant amount of
intellectual content."
"We obviously can't grant credit for a
course that merely teaches a skill,"
commented Benton. "People might want
credit for courses in bicycle riding."
Admitted Benton,"This matter is related
to objectives. If History of Art were to
teach a course in painting so that students
might better understand the techniques of
the masters, I would have to go along. It
would be the same as learning German in
order to read German science texts."
"It is up to my office to implement the
spirit of this policy," he declared.
According to Larry Denton, assistant to
Benton, the new Dean for Undergraduate
Studies, when appointed, will rule on
individual cases of granting credit. The
former Dean, Dr. Carl Swanson, was
responsible for the exchange agreement
with Dean Klitske of Maryland Institute.

The other night when the little woman and I got home from our
encounter group, I said to her, "Isn't it odd, my dear, that colleges
still haven't tried non-verbal communication?"
(Incidentally, the little woman I refer to is not, as you might
think, my wife. My wife is far from a little woman. She is, in fact,
nearly seven feet high and mantled with rippling muscle. She is a fullblooded Chiricahua Apache and holds the world's shotput record -908 feet. The little woman I refer to is someone we found crouching
under the sofa when we rented our flat back in 1924. She has been with
us ever since, although to be perfectly honest, she's really not much
fun to have around. She never speaks except to make a sort of moist,
gagging sound when she's hungry, and she'll often sneak up and tusk
you while you're busy watching television. Still and all, with my wife
away putting the shot most of the time, at least it gives me somebody
to hack around with.)
But I digress. "Isn't it odd, my dear," I said the other night to
the little woman,"that colleges still haven't tried non-verbal communication?" And it is odd. Why do teachers keep talking to students?
Surely they've learned by now that talking is no way to communicate.
It's been proved over and over in encounter groups, T-groups, sensitivity groups and grope groups that people don't really, truly reach
other people with language. How can they? Words, by their very nature, are ambiguous and artificial and conceal more than they reveal.
There is only one way to really, truly communicate with another human being, and that is to touch him and feel him. This is honest and
natural and basic and beautiful and legal in some states.
And yet teachers go right on talking. No wonder they get no feedback. Let us say, for example, that a teacher is trying to get a student
to learn Boyle's law. Talk won't do it, not even if the teacher talks the
whole semester long. But if one day he will simply and silently reach
out and just hold the student for a minute or two, maybe even dance
with him a little bit, he will find that the student has learned not only
Boyle's law but probably the fox trot too.
And what is more, the teacher will discover he has a new friend.
No longer will student and teacher snarl and make coarse gestures
when they see each other on campus. Instead they will run together,
clasp and nuzzle, trade hats, and finally, without a word—for what do
friends need with words?—repair to a nearby tavern for that friendliest of all ceremonies: the sharing of Miller High Life Beer.

Institute Exchange
The good news that Hopkins and the Maryland
Institute of Art have negotiated a long overdue
exchange agreement is marred by the fact that Hopkins
is continuing its warped refusal to grant credit for studio
courses in any of the arts.
The argument used in support of the policy is that such
courses have little or no intellectual content. Unless
one's criteria for intellectual content is absurdly based
on the number of papers, tests and lectures a course has
to offer, then this contention is clearly invalid.
Far more distressing than the actual denial of credit is
the attitude that is indicated by and lies behind the
policy. It is this same attitude that was responsible for
the attempted suppression of Dr. Wickwire's courses.
Such intellectual elitism clouds Hopkins' future as a
viable educational institution.
This elitism implies a belief in a hierarchical value
system, with the supposedly pure intellectual activity of
Hopkins at the top and all that mucking around with
hands and feet and social problems ranked somewhere
down below. Inherent, too, in this system is the notion
that education and "pure" intellectual activity is
separate and distinct from worldly affairs, such as
learning a trade, acquiring a skill or becoming socially
involved. Such an education needs the thin air of the
ivory tower.
It might be argued that no such elitism exists, but that
Hopkins merely wants to preserve its character as an
academic liberal arts institution. Homewood however is
hardly in danger of becoming a center for fine arts.
Rigid divisions between fields of study and discipline
are breaking down; education is moving away from
specialization to a mere loosely structured experience.
With departments here already disappearing,
professors soon to follow, degree credit should be
granted to students who step beyond the narrow
confines of the Homewood campus.

Same Old Song
As Dean Benton put it this week, the primary problem
at Hopkins is how best to fit undergraduate education
into a graduate-oriented framework. We would state the
problem a little differently, putting forth a solution in
the body of our statement. That solution is simple--bend
the graduate framework.
Unfortunately, all the embarrassing statistics in the
world and we don't mean to single out biology--won't
improve the attitude of a faculty that is less than excited
about teaching in general, and undergraduate teaching
in particular. The statistics may, in themselves, even
prove irrelevant. We won't know until there has been an
exchange of information.
What is needed is a give and take between faculty and
students at the departmental level. We have repeated
this often and the solution seems so simple to
implement, that we can't understand why more
aepartments have not given it a try. Certainly, if there is
a genuine attempt on the part of the faculty to involve
students in their own educations and undergraduates
prove unwilling to lend a hand, the undergraduate
population here would have little right to gripe about
whatever they were fed in the way of courses.
The reasoning, however, that the preponderance of
area majors precludes participation in decision-making
at the departmental level, is just an excuse. Why not, as
we have also proposed before, permit area majors, most
of whom have a concentrate field anyway, choose a
department to be attached to. Undergraduates don't
want departmental control. They simply want a say.
We will go on beating the same bushes until we get a
response.

away putting the shot most of the time, at least it gives me somebody
to hack around with.)
But I digress. "Isn't it odd, my dear," I said the other night to
the little woman,"that colleges still haven't tried non-verbal communication?" And it is odd. Why do teachers keep talking to students?
Surely they've learned by now that talking is no way to communicate.
It's been proved over and over in encounter groups, T-groups, sensitivity groups and grope groups that people don't really, truly reach
other people with language. How can they? Words, by their very nature, are ambiguous and artificial and conceal more than they reveal.
There is only one way to really, truly communicate with another human being, and that is to touch him and feel him. This is honest and
natural and basic and beautiful and legal in some states.
And yet teachers go right on talking. No wonder they get no feedback. Let us say, for example, that a teacher is trying to get a student
to learn Boyle's law. Talk won't do it, not even if the teacher talks the
whole semester long. But if one day he will simply and silently reach
out and just hold the student for a minute or two, maybe even dance
with him a little bit, he will find that the student has learned not only
Boyle's law but probably the fox trot too.
And what is more, the teacher will discover he has a new friend.
No longer will student and teacher snarl and make coarse gestures
when they see each other on campus. Instead they will run together,
clasp and nuzzle, trade hats, and finally, without a word—for what do
friends need with words?—repair to a nearby tavern for that friendliest of all ceremonies: the sharing of Miller High Life Beer.

Institute Exchange
The good news that Hopkins and the Maryland
Institute of Art have negotiated a long overdue
exchange agreement is marred by the fact that Hopkins
is continuing its warped refusal to grant credit for studio
courses in any of the arts.
The argument used in support of the policy is that such
courses have little or no intellectual content. Unless
one's criteria for intellectual content is absurdly based
on the number of papers, tests and lectures a course has
to offer, then this contention is clearly invalid.
Far more distressing than the actual denial of credit is
the attitude that is indicated by and lies behind the
policy. It is this same attitude that was responsible for
the attempted suppression of Dr. Wickwire's courses.
Such intellectual elitism clouds Hopkins' future as a
viable educational institution.
This elitism implies a belief in a hierarchical value
system, with the supposedly pure intellectual activity of
Hopkins at the top and all that mucking around with
hands and feet and social problems ranked somewhere
down below. Inherent, too, in this system is the notion
that education and "pure" intellectual activity is
separate and distinct from worldly affairs, such as
learning a trade, acquiring a skill or becoming socially
involved. Such an education needs the thin air of the
ivory tower.
It might be argued that no such elitism exists, but that
Hopkins merely wants to preserve its character as an
academic liberal arts institution. Homewood however is
hardly in danger of becoming a center for fine arts.
Rigid divisions between fields of study and discipline
are breaking down; education is moving away from
specialization to a mere loosely structured experience.
With departments here already disappearing,
professors soon to follow, degree credit should be
granted to students who step beyond the narrow
confines of the Homewood campus.

Same Old Song
As Dean Benton put it this week, the primary problem
at Hopkins is how best to fit undergraduate education
into a graduate-oriented framework. We would state the
problem a little differently, putting forth a solution in
the body of our statement. That solution is simple--bend
the graduate framework.
Unfortunately, all the embarrassing statistics in the
world and we don't mean to single out biology--won't
improve the attitude of a faculty that is less than excited
about teaching in general, and undergraduate teaching
in particular. The statistics may, in themselves, even
prove irrelevant. We won't know until there has been an
exchange of information.
What is needed is a give and take between faculty and
students at the departmental level. We have repeated
this often and the solution seems so simple to
implement, that we can't understand why more
aepartments have not given it a try. Certainly, if there is
a genuine attempt on the part of the faculty to involve
students in their own educations and undergraduates
prove unwilling to lend a hand, the undergraduate
population here would have little right to gripe about
whatever they were fed in the way of courses.
The reasoning, however, that the preponderance of
area majors precludes participation in decision-making
at the departmental level, is just an excuse. Why not, as
we have also proposed before, permit area majors, most
of whom have a concentrate field anyway, choose a
department to be attached to. Undergraduates don't
want departmental control. They simply want a say.
We will go on beating the same bushes until we get a
response.

wonder what reality is."
